quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But if I said you had to write a spec for your career, what does success look like? How are you going to get there?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable framework for treating career planning like product work—define success and a plan rather than drifting.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The workplace is really favoring people who can speak up.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A clear observation about the incentive structure at work that introverts can proactively design around.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But instead, what if I called it educating about all the great work your team has been doing?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A reframe that makes “self-promotion” feel like a service—sharing impact as education and advocacy for the team.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The most important career decision you make is who you marry.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that highlights how personal life choices can be the biggest lever on career trajectory.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You will have a much more successful career if your home life is in balance. It's like a yin and a yang.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Actionable advice to invest in stability outside work as a prerequisite for sustained performance and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
quotes.text: Always be learning, and I tell this to everybody, so I often tell people, someone who's always learning is always going to exceed someone who's the expert today.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A clear career principle that prioritizes continuous learning over relying on current expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
quotes.text: The one thing about school is that we go to school and there's such a thing as getting a hundred on the test, a perfect score on the SAT, graduating with a 4.0. Well, there's nothing like that in careers, right?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A reframing that challenges the “finish line” mindset and emphasizes careers as ongoing, non-scored growth.

quotes.topic_title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
quotes.text: And that's what I have always held, which is each job I took, I didn't necessarily qualify for it. I wasn't necessarily the very best at it, and so it became the student of being better at that job.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical approach to taking stretch roles and using them as deliberate learning vehicles.

quotes.topic_title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
quotes.text: And so I always balanced learning and impact, which was you can have the most impact, the job you know the best, but then you stop learning. And if you're learning all the time, you're not necessarily having impact.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable tradeoff model for alternating between mastery/impact and beginner/learning phases.

quotes.topic_title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
quotes.text: So how do you keep going back and forth and back and forth so that you're not going straight up a lot or you're actually laddering back and forth into different things where you're having an amazing time where you know everything and then you're the newbie again and learning new things, and you're incorporating what you used to know into what you're learning and the impact that you have today and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete career-navigation heuristic: intentionally oscillate between expertise and novice roles to compound growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Tired of bouncing around multiple tools to uncover what's really happening inside your product? With all the tools you need in one simple to use platform, Pendo makes it easy to answer critical questions about how users are engaging with your product and then turn those insights into action.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable workflow: consolidate tooling to understand user behavior and convert insights into product changes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience. Next, Pendo lets you deploy in-app guides that lead users through the actions that matter most. Then Pendo integrates user feedback so that you can capture and analyze what people actually want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a practical three-part methodology (analytics → guidance → feedback) for improving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm not surprised at all that over 10,000 companies use it today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals market validation and widespread usage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and skim provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A forward-looking reminder for SaaS builders to plan for enterprise requirements as a predictable stage of growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop in replacement for auth zero and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, actionable comparison and pricing detail that can influence build-vs-buy decisions for auth/enterprise features.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
quotes.text: And embarrassingly I went to the first day of work and I said to Amy Clement, who was the VP of product at the time, and I said, "Okay, I literally have no idea what this product job is."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights that it’s possible to start in PM without prior mastery if you’re willing to be candid and learn fast on the job.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
quotes.text: She actually showed me, she said, "All those ideas you had, all that energy you've had around building these things, we go do that. Let's go do it."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Emphasizes that strong product instincts and user-driven ideas can be the raw material for PM execution.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
quotes.text: And she said, "Well, you write down what you want to build and you work with the engineers to do it."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A simple, actionable mental model for PM work: clarify what to build, then partner with engineering to ship it.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
quotes.text: Those first few years, I just learned so much about the craft of building, how to really think through product use cases, how to think through what customers wanted, not just the customer of one, myself, but really what true customers and customer cohorts wanted.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical shift from personal intuition to cohort-based customer thinking as a core PM skill.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
quotes.text: I came with a curiosity and I think that's what made me a great product manager was that I didn't have a set way of doing things. There wasn't some playbook I was trying to play. There wasn't some framework, but instead I was willing to learn.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that flexibility and curiosity can outperform rigid adherence to PM playbooks early on.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
quotes.text: Coming in with humbleness was really important, but during the interview process, actually, I didn't realize this, but they asked me questions as if I was a product manager, as if I knew what I was doing.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mindset shift for interviews: expect to be evaluated as if you already hold the role, while staying humble.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
quotes.text: I think when you have passion around a product or passion around a company or around a business model or around something, it shows.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Emphasizes that authentic enthusiasm is observable and can substitute for missing formal experience in interviews.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
quotes.text: And so it's not necessarily faking the enthusiasm or faking the idea that you want to work there, but you don't have to know how to write this spec or PRD or briefings or anything like that.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterintuitively reframes “fake it till you make it” as not needing PM artifacts to demonstrate readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
quotes.text: Show who you are and why you care.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A simple, actionable directive for candidates to lead with motivation and personal connection to the work.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
quotes.text: But you have to be able to fall in love with the problem. You have to fall in love, not with the product, but I said the problem, right? The use case. What problem are you trying to solve?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for PM interviews: anchor your narrative in deep problem obsession and customer use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
quotes.text: The people who were most successful were the ones who actually through adversity, learned to turn stumbling blocks into stepping stones.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for reframing setbacks into concrete progress drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
quotes.text: They were the ones who got hard feedback and then came back stronger because now they learned what to do differently.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: treat tough feedback as a learning loop that changes future behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
quotes.text: They were the ones who products failed, but they said, "You know what? I'm going to turn this failure into success. I'm going to take those lessons and make this company stronger."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented approach to post-mortems: convert failure lessons into organizational strength.

quotes.topic_title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
quotes.text: Trees are strong because they bend in the wind, because they're tested, because it's cold, because it's windy, because there's conditions.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A vivid resilience analogy that reinforces why stressors and constraints build durability over time.

quotes.topic_title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
quotes.text: You want to have enough adversity that you learn to overcome so that you can build stronger over time and build resilience in your career.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice: seek the right dose of challenge to develop long-term resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
quotes.text: And he said, "Not only will I not give you that job, you'll never have that job at this company."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A stark example of direct career feedback that forces a decision about how to respond when a desired path is closed off.

quotes.topic_title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
quotes.text: And I had to decide each time like, "What do I do with this information?"
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable decision point: treat feedback as an input and choose an intentional response rather than reacting emotionally.

quotes.topic_title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
quotes.text: Actually, I decided I was going to turn the job I had and the job I wanted, and that's a choice.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical agency model: reshape your current scope toward your desired role instead of waiting for permission or a title change.

quotes.topic_title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
quotes.text: But at the same time it was a reminder that you're not right for every job even if you think you are.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career lesson that reframes rejection as fit mismatch rather than personal failure.

quotes.topic_title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
quotes.text: And that you can take the raw materials of what you have and turn it into what you want.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable methodology for practitioners: inventory existing assets (team, mandate, resources) and recombine them into the outcome you’re aiming for.

quotes.topic_title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
quotes.text: The thing that you have to remember is the failure rate for something like this is very high.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A grounding reminder that zero-to-one efforts inside big companies should be managed with an expectation of frequent failure, not linear progress.

quotes.topic_title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
quotes.text: But actually everything in the company is like, "Let's do the most important thing."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Explains why new bets struggle for resources in large companies: they constantly compete against the organization’s highest-priority work.

quotes.topic_title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
quotes.text: The thing that I think a lot of large companies don't realize is that you can love something to death.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that too much attention and oversight can kill early-stage innovation before it has room to iterate.

quotes.topic_title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
quotes.text: We actually tested five or six versions of the ads product before we got it to take off and it took months, and then we were on the verge of death multiple times.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example of the iteration volume and near-failure dynamics practitioners should plan for when incubating new products.

quotes.topic_title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
quotes.text: It's the long slog that makes it really hard. In a company, you end up getting cut if you're the long slog product.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for internal startups: avoid drawn-out, ambiguous progress by pruning/pivoting quickly to survive org-level prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for innovation: patience and portfolio thinking
quotes.text: I think the most important part of the environment is really patience. And again, this is a portfolio strategy and I tell every PM who... I used to do a new hire PM class and I say, "Look, a lot of you are going to go into the core product and your job is to grow X by 3 to 5% every six months. Growing engagement or growing sessions or maybe growing video views or whatever your metric is, you're trying to grow something 5% and then you exceed expectations."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Frames innovation leadership as requiring patience and a portfolio mindset, contrasting it with predictable core-product growth expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for innovation: patience and portfolio thinking
quotes.text: By the way, a very, very successful company for a new set of products has a 50% hit rate.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark that normalizes failure rates for new-product portfolios.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for innovation: patience and portfolio thinking
quotes.text: So half of you are going to come back in a year and have a different job because that did not work out. Do you have the resilience to do that?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Makes the career risk of zero-to-one work explicit and turns it into a resilience check for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for innovation: patience and portfolio thinking
quotes.text: But if you choose to be the person who works on innovation new products, expect in a year, you might literally have nothing to show for it, but the lessons that you learned. And I think those lessons are really precious and we often underestimate that too.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Reframes “no shipped outcome” as a valid (and undervalued) return on innovation work, emphasizing learning as an asset.

quotes.topic_title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
quotes.text: So the one thing I realized about my role was that I did a lot of... I had five different careers at the company over 11 years.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights a portfolio mindset inside one company—treating roles/projects as distinct career chapters you can intentionally rotate through.

quotes.topic_title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
quotes.text: So you learn the lessons of how to get things done, how to get resource, how to get support when the product is not working, how to not get prunes in the next culling.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Actionable skill checklist for surviving and succeeding in zero-to-one/internal innovation environments.

quotes.topic_title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
quotes.text: But I think for people who are just starting out of the career, it is a very high risk thing to do. So if you're very early in the career, I encourage people just learn the core skills first. You can learn the core skills when there's a lot of stability.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Counterbalances the common “do startups/0-to-1 early” advice by recommending stable environments first to build fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
quotes.text: But I think it reaches a point in your career where you have to decide, when am I going to take the big swing? Because the big swings are the things that you write your career stories about.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Defines a career narrative framework: incremental wins build credibility, but “big swings” create the stories that shape trajectory.

quotes.topic_title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
quotes.text: I encourage everybody to take some time, two, three years in their career when they're ready for the big swing, where if it doesn't work... If it works, you run the team, you run this amazing product. It doesn't work, you can always go back and go back to the core products.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Provides a concrete time-box (2–3 years) and risk-management plan for taking a high-upside bet without permanently derailing your resume.

quotes.topic_title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
quotes.text: By the way, for your PM audience, I want to say this, which is a lot of the greatest PMs are the worst PMs of their careers.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that highlights how strong product skills often don’t translate into intentional career management.

quotes.topic_title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
quotes.text: But if I said you had to write a spec for your career, what's in there? What are your milestones? What are the skills? What are the features that you want to have of your career? How are you going to get there? What does success look like?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete framework for treating career planning like product development with a “spec” and defined components.

quotes.topic_title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
quotes.text: You actually have metrics for your product, and yet you don't have metrics for your career.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to define measurable career outcomes the same way you would define product success metrics.

quotes.topic_title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
quotes.text: I see that happen in a lot of careers, which is my story when you look back, looks great. It looks like it all worked out, but I had almost zero intentionality in any of these.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A cautionary story about survivorship bias and how “successful” career narratives can mask a lack of deliberate planning.

quotes.topic_title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
quotes.text: And so I think having a plan allows you to compare every decision.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical decision-making heuristic: use a plan as a reference point to evaluate opportunities consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
quotes.text: But if you actually aim in the right direction, you can shape your learnings, you can shape your roles you take, you can shape your skills towards the place that you want to go.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical mental model for career planning: pick a direction (not a fixed plan) and use it to intentionally choose roles and skill-building.

quotes.topic_title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
quotes.text: And to really having a measuring stick is this getting me closer or further away from where I go? Can allow you to actually take serial decision making to a place where you're measuring against a long-term goal.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A decision framework for evaluating job offers that arrive one-by-one: use a consistent “closer vs. further” measuring stick tied to a long-term goal.

quotes.topic_title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
quotes.text: First, it's probably going to take you 10 years because look at who's on the board.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example of setting realistic timelines by benchmarking against who already holds the target role (e.g., board seats).

quotes.topic_title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
quotes.text: It's like before you go to Harvard, you have to graduate from elementary school to middle school. You have to take the SAT, you have to apply. I said, "Let's start from the first step and let's break this problem down."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable “work backward and decompose” methodology for turning an ambitious career goal into sequenced, actionable steps.

quotes.topic_title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
quotes.text: But I love that she knew where she wanted to go and she's like, "Even if I don't make it there, I'll be happier having made this journey."
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A values-based reframe that reduces outcome rigidity while preserving direction—optimizing for the journey and growth, not just the destination.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset. It should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Reframes a website from a one-time deliverable into an ongoing growth lever tied to conversion outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 54% of leaders say web updates take too long.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies how common slow web iteration is as a business bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their visual first platform allows you to build, launch, and optimize webpages fast.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights an execution model—rapid build/launch/optimize cycles—that teams can apply to speed up iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: that basically have to learn to be an extrovert as an introvert because in business extroverts are most valued.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career observation that suggests introverts may need to deliberately adopt extroverted behaviors to succeed.

quotes.topic_title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
quotes.text: I wrote this post. It was the secret bias no one talks about, which is the workplace is really favoring people who can speak up.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Names the core systemic bias that hides introverts’ impact and sets up the need for both personal and organizational countermeasures.

quotes.topic_title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
quotes.text: I realized that so much of what products and just general leadership is, is not just doing the work, but actually... It's not just having the product, it's having great product marketing to go with it.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A memorable leadership framework: impact requires both execution and “marketing” your work so others can evaluate it.

quotes.topic_title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
quotes.text: First, I think for the individual is realizing that you are your own best marketer. You have to actually share what you do.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice for introverts to increase visibility and recognition without waiting for the system to change.

quotes.topic_title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
quotes.text: So one of the things that I found was in my leadership teams over the last several years, we had this thing where we all vote, but we vote offline in a document and we put a number in and then we put our comments in.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A concrete inclusive practice (“bias interrupter”) that equalizes input by decoupling thinking from real-time speaking dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
quotes.text: we used to go around in a circle and everybody would give their opinion in a meeting. I do that still today.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A simple meeting mechanism that structurally ensures every voice is heard, countering dominance by the most vocal participants.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
quotes.text: I think we do a disservice when we say we're not good at speaking up because it's a skill like any other.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Reframes speaking up from a personality trait to a learnable skill, making it actionable for introverts.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
quotes.text: You don't have to be comfortable with it. You don't have to love it, but you just have to do it.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A practical standard for building communication muscle: prioritize execution over comfort.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
quotes.text: If you think your self-review is self-promotion, you're just not going to do a great job at it.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Highlights how framing affects performance—seeing it as “self-promotion” creates avoidance and lowers quality.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
quotes.text: What if I called it educating your manager about all the great work your team has been doing? What if I called it helping people see why your team should get more resources?
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: Offers a concrete reframing technique that turns “self-promotion” into advocacy and resource-building for the team.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
quotes.text: If you see it as self-promoting, you will never do it.
quotes.speaker: Deb Liu
quotes.context: A blunt diagnostic: the label you attach to visibility work can be the root cause of inaction.
